summaries.body: Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, is taking a seat on the board of SurveyMonkey, her late husband’s online survey and polling company.
Global poverty has dropped sharply, girls have caught up to boys in primary school enrollment and malaria deaths are down, according to a U.N. report.
The reserves and pitchers for the M.L.B. All-Star teams were announced, with Alex Rodriguez among the notable omissions. The game will be held on July 14.
The U.S. government will pay $1.3 million to the family of a baby who died at a Hawaii military hospital in a settlement of a medical malpractice lawsuit.
When Michael R. Bloomberg's daughter, Emma, gave birth this spring, she and her husband, Chris Frissora, combined their surnames in naming Zelda Violet Frissberg.
New York City agreed to pay more than $330,000 to six Occupy Wall Street protesters who said a police officer doused them with pepper spray without cause in 2011.
The bacterium responsible for the Black Death probably caused small outbreaks of lung disease for thousands of years before it evolved its better-known form, a study said.
A man in Calgary was charged after riding into the sky on a lawn chair with more than 100 helium balloons attached. He sustained minor injuries in a crash landing.
ESPN said it would relocate a celebrity golf tournament from a course owned by Donald Trump following his inflammatory comments about Mexican immigrants.
Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was sentenced to death for the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, filed a preliminary motion for a new trial "in the interests of justice."
Ellen Pao, Reddit's chief executive, apologized to the online message board's users for what she characterized as a history of broken promises and poor communication.

display_asset.credit: Pool photo by John G. Mabanglo

summaries.body: Manu Ginobili said he would return to the San Antonio Spurs for another season. The 37-year-old guard has spent 13 years with the team.
The South Carolina Senate has rejected a proposal for a statewide referendum on the Confederate battle flag outside the State House.
GoPro introduced a smaller, easier to use action camera that will go on sale on July 12, part of its strategy to maintain dominance of the action-camera market.
The United States victory over Japan on Sunday in the Women's World Cup final has set a new ratings high for a soccer telecast in the U.S., Fox Sports reported.
The European Union's top prosecutor said she has been told that smugglers' boats bringing migrants across the Mediterranean to Europe are also carrying ISIS fighters.
Dozens of Afghans protested a court ruling that overturned death sentences for four men convicted of taking part in the mob killing of a woman outside a Kabul shrine.
Waze, the online mapping company owned by Google, is starting a carpooling pilot program in Israel where commuters pay drivers a fee for a ride to and from work.
Dale Earnhardt Jr. won the Coke Zero 400 at the Nascar Daytona speedway Monday, where Austin Dillon crashed. Mr. Dillon walked away but a fan was treated in the hospital.
An Iraqi fighter jet, made by Russia, accidentally dropped a bomb over a Baghdad neighborhood, killing at least 12 people on the ground, Iraqi officials said.
Princess Charlotte, the baby daughter of Prince William and his wife, Kate, was christened on Sunday. It was the family's first public outing together since her birth in May.
Rory McIlroy, the top-ranked golfer, said he suffered a "total rupture" of an ankle ligament while playing soccer with friends on Saturday.

posts.footer: The Times's Rome bureau chief, who is following the pope on his trip to South America, via Twitter

summaries.body: Francis can start his messaging today, so things to look for: Environment? Will he talk about oil exploration plans in Ecuador? The Amazon?

posts.footer: The Times's Tehran bureau chief, via Twitter

summaries.body: After days of pessimism Iran state TV now hinting nuclear deal is coming: "The Americans have compromised on their own redlines."
A Singapore court sentenced Amos Yee, a teenager who criticized the late Lee Kuan Yew online, to four weeks' detention, which he has already served. He was expected to go free.

display_asset.caption: Artwork by Ms. Aaron for both “Sesame Street” and an independent project to encourage children to eat vegetables.

summaries.body: Jane Aaron, a filmmaker who died last month at 67, made nearly 200 animated shorts on “Sesame Street” introducing children to letters, numbers and other concepts.
Bombs went off at a crowded mosque and a restaurant in the Nigerian city of Jos, killing 44 people, witnesses said.

posts.footer: Yanis Varoufakis, announcing on his blog that he would resign from his post as Greece's finance minister to help Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras reach a better deal in negotiations with the nation's creditors

summaries.body: I shall support fully Prime Minister Tsipras, the new minister of finance and our government.
The head of Thailand's army dismissed calls to release 14 students who are being held for protesting military rule.

display_asset.caption: Kevin Keller, a gay character, was introduced into Archie Comics in 2010.

summaries.body: In an effort to mirror changing attitudes, publishers are promoting a wider selection of gay-themed comic books.
Burt Shavitz, the co-founder of Burt's Bees, whose products bore his name and likeness, died at 80. The cosmetics company said he had "left for greener fields and wilder woods."
The Philippines confirmed its second case of MERS, a foreigner who had flown to Manila from the Middle East. The country's first MERS patient was diagnosed in January.
A Chinese man accused of spreading rumors that people had jumped off buildings in Beijing because of falling stock prices was arrested, state media reported.
Seven people were fatally shot in Chicago over the holiday weekend, including a 7-year-old boy who was celebrating the Fourth of July with his family, the police said.
A U.S. Army soldier admitted in federal court that he took $100,000 in cash bribes from vendors seeking contracts while he was in Afghanistan, prosectors said.
Testing children's reactions to pleasant and unpleasant odors may help diagnose autism, a new study suggests.
A woman died from measles in Washington State, officials said. It is the first measles death in the U.S. in 12 years.
The N.F.L. suspended Antonio Gates, the San Diego Chargers tight end, for four games for violating the league's policy on performance-enhancing drugs.
Dollar Tree and Family Dollar agreed to sell 330 Family Dollar stores to settle F.T.C. charges that a merger would likely be anticompetitive.

display_asset.caption: The Times food editor Sam Sifton reads a selection of Twitter responses to a recipe for guacamole with peas, including one from President Obama.
display_asset.credit: Produced by Caitlin Prentke and Sam Sifton
display_asset.title: The Times Responds to ‘Peacamole’ Tweets

summaries.body: A recipe for guacamole with peas didn't go over all that well with some of our readers. The Times's food editor, Sam Sifton, reads some of the mean tweets.

display_asset.caption: Bystanders and emergency personnel assisted a teenage girl at the scene of a shark attack last month in Oak Island, N.C.
display_asset.credit: Steve Bouser/The Pilot, via Associated Press

summaries.body: After a series of shark attacks off North Carolina's coast, Gov. Pat McCrory said officials are trying to find ways to keep the key tourism region safe for visitors.
In a setback for interns, an appeals court vacated a previous ruling in favor of two men who said their unpaid work on the movie "Black Swan" violated laws.
Mayor Muriel Bowser and other officials, speaking about the lockdown at the Washington Navy Yard, said there was no evidence of a gunman or that shots were fired.
Five United Nations peacekeepers were killed and six were severely wounded in an attack on their convoy in northern Mali, a spokeswoman said.

display_asset.caption: Women carried the coffin of Farkhunda, who was lynched by a mob, during her funeral in Kabul, Afghanistan, in March.

summaries.body: An Afghan court has overturned the death sentences of four men convicted in the lynching of a woman falsely accused of burning the Quran, a lawyer and a politician said.
The Washington Navy Yard was locked down after reports that shots were fired. Roads were closed, and workers were told to stay in place. The Navy said it was investigating.
A poll shows that 57 percent of white Americans see the Confederate flag more as a symbol of Southern pride than of racism, and 72 percent of blacks see it as racist.
The Shanghai Composite Index in China fell 3.5 percent amid doubts over government measures to support equities.

display_asset.caption: Former Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo of South Korea, center, in February. Mr. Lee was indicted on Thursday on a charge of receiving illegal political funds.

summaries.body: Lee Wan-koo, who resigned as South Korea's prime minister in April, was indicted on charges of accepting illegal campaign funds from a businessman who later killed himself.

posts.footer: A journalist covering the Greek crisis for The New York Times in Athens, referring to the finance minister and prime minister, via Twitter

summaries.body: So, @yanisvaroufakis tells @BloombergTV he'll resign in case of 'Yes' vote in referendum. What about @tsipras_eu ?
Law enforcement officials in Switzerland said they received a formal request from the United States to extradite seven FIFA officials who were arrested in May.
A woman with amnesia, whose identity perplexed the F.B.I., Interpol and thousands of amateur sleuths, was identified after her nephew saw an online news report.

posts.footer: A Channel News Asia correspondent in the Philippines, via Twitter

summaries.body: BREAKING: Boat capsizes in the Philippines with 173 on board. Search and rescue operations underway
Another shark attack has been reported on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, the state's seventh this year. The victim survived despite being pulled underwater.
The police in England are treating the death of John "Goldfinger" Palmer, a convicted con man thought to have died as a result of natural causes, as a murder inquiry.
Most children in Syria now work to support their families, Save the Children and Unicef said. Before the war, nearly all who were old enough went to school.

display_asset.caption: Migrants jumped out of a truck in Calais after being spotted by French officers as they tried to cross to England on Wednesday.

summaries.body: In the French port of Calais, a strike by ferry workers has become tangled in Europe’s migration crisis, as drivers say their idled trucks have been besieged by migrants.
The military plane that crashed into an Indonesian city, killing more than 140, had a propeller "abnormality" indicating a stalled engine, the air force chief said.
The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a rule that would let companies take bonuses back from senior executives if they were based on flawed accounting.
Billy Joel set a Madison Square Garden record with his 65th show there Wednesday night. No single artist has performed there more often.

posts.footer: San Thar Aung, a Buddhist in Myanmar, on the opposition leader, who has been criticized by rights groups for not speaking out for persecuted Muslims, via The Wall Street Journal

summaries.body: We in Rakhine state hate Aung San Suu Kyi. She has spoken out too strongly for the Muslims, and blamed us unfairly.

display_asset.caption: A small number of barricades and traffic cones in front of Emanuel A.M.E Church in Charleston, S.C. on Tuesday. Visitors and residents have continued to pay their respects two weeks after the killings there.
display_asset.credit: Stephen B. Morton for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two weeks after the killings there, Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., is still drawing visitors day and night, and an outdoor memorial to the victims continues to grow.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse | The New York Times

summaries.body: A 19-year-old student who was badly burned when a cloud of colored powder caught fire at a Taiwan water park died from his injuries, the second fatality from the incident.

display_asset.caption: An 11th-century bronze statue depicting Saint Manikkavichavakar was handed over by a New York collector who had been misled into buying it by fraudulent paperwork, federal officials said.

summaries.body: An 11th-century bronze statue from India said to have been smuggled into the United States by a Manhattan art dealer was turned over to federal officials by an art collector.
A man who killed a 9-year-old on New York's Upper West Side in 2010 punched his lawyer in the face after a jury found him not criminally responsible by reason of insanity.
Ten South Koreans were killed when a bus in northeastern China fell off a bridge, Chinese state-run news media reported.
Stephen Colbert made an unannounced appearance as guest host of a public-access television show in Monroe, Mich., where he interviewed the rapper Eminem.
Visa and MasterCard cut ties with Backpage.com after law enforcement officials said the classified advertising website facilitates prostitution and sex trafficking.
Episcopalians voted to allow religious weddings for gay couples, solidifying the church's embrace of gay rights.

display_asset.credit: Jason Franson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Japan defeated England, 2-1, in the Women's World Cup semifinals and will play the U.S. for the title on Sunday.
European police said they would create a new unit aimed at discovering and dismantling social media accounts that Islamist radicals use for recruitment and propaganda.
Prince removed his music from all streaming services except for Tidal. There has not yet been an explanation.
A Saudi prince vowed to give away his entire $32 billion fortune to charitable causes in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere. He gave no time frame.

display_asset.caption: President Obama picked up Kelly Bryant, who had written him a letter about how the health law had improved her life, from her home in Nashville on Wednesday.  He later spoke at an event promoting the law.

summaries.body: President Obama, above with a woman who had written to him, flew into mostly Republican territory on Wednesday to push for expanding health care to more poor people.
The Muslim Brotherhood called for a rebellion against President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi, saying its leaders were killed in a Cairo apartment on Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: Ben Burley of Breaking Benjamin in 2008.

summaries.body: Breaking Benjamin's "Dark Before Dawn" debuted atop the Billboard album chart this week. It is the rock band's first No. 1 album.
Kevin Love, one of the top free agents available in the N.B.A., signed again with the Cleveland Cavaliers, saying he has "unfinished business."
Automakers rode the wave of surging sales for yet another month in June, with sales up nearly across the board. But one company was left out: General Motors.
Silent for 33 years, Wolf volcano in the Galápagos Islands released an explosive howl a few weeks ago, spewing fire and ash nearly 50,000 feet high. NASA released images.
Liberian officials confirmed a second Ebola case in the town where the virus was recently detected on a teenager's corpse, seven weeks after Liberia was declared Ebola-free.
The U.N. declared its highest-level humanitarian emergency in Yemen, where over 80 percent of the population needs aid. Officials said the country is one step away from famine.
Macy’s, the department store chain, is ending its relationship with Donald J. Trump and phasing out his line of clothing after his remarks about Mexican immigrants.
President Obama, calling it a "historic step," said the United States and Cuba had agreed to reopen embassies in each other’s capitals.
Heavy rainfall over the past three days triggered devastating mudslides in Darjeeling, India, that left at least 30 dead and many others missing.
The U.S. private sector ramped up hiring in June, adding 237,000 jobs, the largest number in six months.
A woman fought off bees, survived on apples and started a wildfire to summon help after giving birth in a lonely stretch of Northern California forest, she told local television.
Britain is experiencing its hottest day in nine years, with temperatures of up to 93 degrees in some areas.
Today is "pay day" for Bobby Bonilla, the baseball player whose career ended in 2001. The Mets must pay him about $1.2 million every year until his contract expires in 2035.
The World Food Program said it had to reduce food aid for Syrian refugees in Lebanon because of a funding crisis and may have to halt food support for most refugees in Jordan.

display_asset.credit: Clarendon County Fire Department, via Reuters

summaries.body: Another predominantly African-American church has burned in the South, the latest in a string of fires that has put congregations on edge.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: Toyota said Julie Hamp, the highest-ranking female executive in its history, had resigned. She was arrested in Japan last month on suspicion of importing a banned painkiller.
A woman turned up in a town in California, with a diagnosis of cancer, suffering from amnesia and speaking some words with an Australian accent.
A long-awaited report from the Airports Commission recommends building a third runway at Heathrow, rather than a second at Gatwick, to serve London.

posts.footer: Jon Bon Jovi, who, a day after hosting a Hillary Rodham Clinton fundraiser, let Chris Christie use his song “Who Says You Can’t Go Home” for his presidential campaign announcement, via Politico

summaries.body: My friendships are apolitical, and yes, I absolutely gave him permission to use my songs.
A record 137,000 people crossed the Mediterranean Sea in the first half of this year trying to reach the shores of Europe, the United Nations said.

posts.footer: The South China Morning Post | The New York Times

summaries.body: China's rubber-stamp legislature passed a far-reaching national security law that analysts said would strengthen the Communist Party's hold on power.
Uber criticized a proposal to put a freeze on for-hire vehicle licenses in New York City while a traffic-congestion study is conducted, calling it an attempt to limit competition.
A closely watched survey found Japanese businesses in an upbeat mood, which analysts said should ease pressure on the central bank to expand monetary stimulus.
Aid officials may add Yemen to a list of the world’s most severe humanitarian crises, putting pressure on the Saudi-led military coalition there. Above, Sana, the capital.
The F.B.I. is investigating several physical attacks on high-capacity Internet cables in the San Francisco Bay Area over the past year, including one on Tuesday.
